review.title: Investigating the Characteristics of One-Sided Matching Mechanisms Under Various Preferences and Risk Attitudes
review.abstract: One-sided matching mechanisms are fundamental for assigning a set of indivisible objects to a set of self-interested agents when monetary transfers are not allowed. Two widely-studied randomized mechanisms in multiagent settings are the Random Serial Dictatorship (RSD) and the Probabilistic Serial Rule (PS). Both mechanisms require only that agents specify ordinal preferences and have a number of desirable economic and computational properties. However, the induced outcomes of the mechanisms are often incomparable and thus there are challenges when it comes to deciding which mechanism to adopt in practice. In this paper, we first consider the space of general ordinal preferences and provide empirical results on the (in)comparability of RSD and PS. We analyze their respective economic properties under general and lexicographic preferences. We then instantiate utility functions with the goal of gaining insights on the manipulability, efficiency, and envyfreeness of the mechanisms under different risk-attitude models. Our results hold under various preference distribution models, which further confirm the broad use of RSD in most practical applications.
histories: arXiv admin note: text overlap witharXiv:1503.01488
review.COMMENTS: arXiv admin note: text overlap witharXiv:1503.01488

metadata.title: Investigating the Characteristics of One-Sided Matching Mechanisms Under Various Preferences and Risk Attitudes

sections.text: In this paper, we first examine the area of general ordinal preferences and provide empirical results on the (in-) comparability of RSD and PS. We analyze their respective economic characteristics under general and lexicographic preferences. We then instantiate utility functions with the aim of gaining insights into the manipulability, efficiency and absence of envy of the mechanisms under different risk setting models. Our results are based on various preference distribution models, which further confirm the broad application of RSD in most practical applications.Keywords One-sided matching · Random serial dictatorship · Probabilistic serial rule · Strategic security · Social welfare · Fairness · Risk settings

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This year, it is closer than ever before in the history of the country.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that it has never come as far as it has this year.

sections.heading: 4 General and Lexicographic Preferences
sections.text: The theoretical properties of PS and RSD are considered to be only limited insights into their practical applications. In particular, when deciding which mechanisms to apply in different constellations, the incomparability of PS and RSD is an ambiguous choice in terms of efficiency, manipulability and encyclopaedia. Thus, we examine the properties of RSD and PS in the space of all possible preference profiles as well as the different preferences. Lexicon preferences are present in various fields of application and have been extensively studied in artificial intelligence and multi-agent systems as a means of assessing allocations based on ordinary preferences. [18, 44] Under lexicographic preferences, an assignment is made that assigns a higher probability to the top ranking object that we are always preferred to other assignments, regardless of the probabilities we have assigned to the objects in the next positions.

sections.heading: 6 Results
sections.text: For our experiments, we vary three parameters: the number of agents n, the number of objects m, and the risk setting factor α. Each data point in the graphs shows the mean across all possible preference profiles. We examine the same settings as in Section 4, when n ≥ m and n < m. For each welfare function, we look at homogeneous populations of agents in which agents have the same risk settings but may have different preferences. To compare social welfare, we examine the percentage change (or improvement) in the social well-being of PS compared to RSD under different benefit models. That is, in which areas of the PS profile is manipulable.

sections.heading: 7 Other Ranking Distribution Models
sections.text: In this section, we will use variations of two statistical models commonly used to capture realistic preference distributions in a population of players (= 7). Substantial work in calculating social choices and machine learning will allow us to use these statistical models to capture the distribution of ranking preferences in a population of agents [8,30,31]. We will focus on Mallows models and Polya-Eggenberger Urn models (Urn) when the preferences of agent models are distributed around a reference ranking that is proportional to the removal of Kendall-Tau (KT) [25, 26]. Henceforth, preferences closer to the reference ranking will appear more likely in the population. In other words, agent preferences differ from the reference ranking with decreasing probability that rankings will move away from the reference. Mallows models are parameterized by a reference ranking and a dispersion ranking parameter (we use rankings in view of a form ranking).

sections.heading: 8 Related Literature
sections.text: Svensson showed that the serial dictatorship is the only deterministic mechanism that is strategically secure, but not in terms of efficiency [2]. Bogomolnaia and Moulin noted the inefficiency of RSD from the perspective of the former and characterized the classification mechanisms of the former. They suggested that the serial mechanism was an efficient and energy-saving one.

sections.heading: 10 Design Recommendations for Multiagent Systems Practitioners
sections.text: Our work in this paper can be used to help designers of multi-agent systems who need to solve assignment problems. However, if a designer urgently needs sd efficiency, then PS's theoretical results indicate that it is better than RSD. However, our results show that PS is highly susceptible to manipulation for various combinations of agents and objects. This manipulation and the potential gain from manipulation become more difficult especially when agents are risk averse and designers need to take this into account. On the other hand, while RSD theoretically does not guarantee sd efficiency, our results show that it tends to do quite well - sometimes even better than PS in terms of social welfare. RSD also has the added advantage of being sd-strategically secure, and is therefore not vulnerable to the manipulation problems of PS. Although the calculation of RSD probabilities (fractional assignments) is hard [6, 45], RSD is easy to put into practice.

metadata.abstractText: One-sided matching mechanisms are fundamental for assigning a set of indivisible objects to a set of self-interested agents when monetary transfers are not allowed. Two widely-studied randomized mechanisms in multiagent settings are the Random Serial Dictatorship (RSD) and the Probabilistic Serial Rule (PS). Both mechanisms require only that agents specify ordinal preferences and have a number of desirable economic and computational properties. However, the induced outcomes of the mechanisms are often incomparable and thus there are challenges when it comes to deciding which mechanism to adopt in practice. In this paper, we first consider the space of general ordinal preferences and provide empirical results on the (in)comparability of RSD and PS. We analyze their respective economic properties under general and lexicographic preferences. We then instantiate utility functions with the goal of gaining insights on the manipulability, efficiency, and envyfreeness of the mechanisms under different riskattitude models. Our results hold under various preference distribution models, which further confirm the broad use of RSD in most practical applications.
